translator_notes: 「凡例」(fanli) refers to editorial principles or conventions - a traditional feature of Chinese scholarly editions explaining textual methodology
「云雨」(clouds and rain) is a classical Chinese euphemism for sexual intimacy, derived from the legend of King Xiang of Chu's dream of a goddess
「葫芦案」(gourd case) is a pun - 葫芦 sounds like 糊涂 (muddled/confused), suggesting an incomprehensible or absurdly judged case
「风月鉴」(Mirror of Romance) - 风月 literally means wind and moon, but idiomatically refers to romantic or sensual affairs
「黄泉」(Yellow Springs) refers to the underworld in Chinese mythology - the road to the afterlife
Chapters 17 and 18 share the same title, indicating they were originally one chapter later divided
research_notes: The chapter titles in Honglou Meng follow a parallel structure common in classical Chinese fiction, with two seven-character phrases per title
Each title summarizes two key events or themes of the chapter, often juxtaposing contrasting situations
The page numbers correspond to the internal pagination of this specific collated edition
